Under Trudeau, Canada has turned its back to the world. Our relationships with allies and partners around the world are worse than they have been in living memory. Appeasing China has brought zero benefits to Canada or Canadians, including those languishing in Chinese prisons. In pursuit of a UN Security Council seat, Trudeau has stopped standing up for human rights around the world, for fear of offending the dictators whose votes he craves, while letting down our allies.

Trudeau’s approach to the world – appeasing dictators and ceding Canadian sovereignty to institutions like the United Nations – has failed.

Canada and the world deserve a strong and principled foreign policy that truly aligns with Canadian values and interests – one that focusses on strengthening alliances with like-minded countries, facing down the threat posed by China, and aggressively championing human rights.

TO RESTORE CANADA’S PLACE IN THE WORLD, AN O’TOOLE GOVERNMENT WILL:

Make Canada a leader in promoting freedom and human rights around the world, standing with those, such as the people of Hong Kong, Taiwan, Syria and Iran, fighting for their freedom and championing the cause of oppressed peoples including Tibetans, Uighurs and Kurds.

Take Canada’s place as an Indo-Pacific nation seriously by reversing Trudeau’s appeasement of Communist China and degrading democratic India.

Recognize the threat posed by the Chinese Communist regime and develop a plan, including:

Working in cooperation with countries like Australia, South Korea, and Japan,

Elevating our relationship with India,

Partnering with like-minded countries across the Indo-Pacific region, enhancing security, trade and other ties,

Cracking down on the efforts of the Chinese Communist Party to infiltrate Canadian institutions and intimidate Chinese-Canadians,

Banning Huawei from participating in 5G,

Limiting the role of Chinese state-owned enterprises in Canada’s economy.

Placing caveats on the One China policy based on how Beijing responds to concerns about the One Country, Two Systems Agreement in Hong Kong, respect for Taiwanese participation in Multi-lateral UN agencies, respect and reconciliation with His Holiness the Dalai Lama and the Tibetan people, and treatment of persecuted religious communities of Uighurs, and

Suspending the Canada-China Legislative Association. The Parliament of Canada will not legitimize the undemocratic nature of the Chinese National Party Congress.

If Michael Spavor and Michael Kovrig remain in detention when the Conservative government is formed, a 30-day period will be given for their release before the imposition of Magnitsky sanctions on the President, Premier of the State Council , the Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National Party Congress and the President of the Supreme People’s Court. We will also urge use of Magnitsky sanctions by our allies as well.
